page.title: 03LANDSCAPE OF DOWNS,EDINGTON.
page.content: Longcombe Bottom is part of the head of a valley system, now dry, that drained south and then east through Imber. Dung,from the grazing of sheep over hundreds of years, has enriched the poor chalk soil. During and after the l939/l945 War the ploughing of the turf to grow cereals produced a rich loam. The flints help warm this soil. Downland grass, close grazed by sheep and rabbits, allows the characteristic chalkland flora to flourish. Coarse grasses grow on the ungrazed areas of the firing ranges. On a clear day, from the high ground, you can see for miles across the clay vale to the north. To the south are the undulating downs with a few small clumps of beech trees and the deep sided narrow combes where sheep graze.
